summary: On June 9, 2015, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi entered a final judgment against Eric Lott, Jr., a convicted felon who was sentenced to serve twenty years in the custody of the Mississippi Department of Corrections.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Jackson, Mississippi, alleges that Lott was denied effective assistance of counsel when he was indicted for the murder of his girlfriend, Konswaylo Durr.  According to the complaint, Lott told the trial judge that he was afraid of being seriously injured by a larger, though unarmed, victim, and that he had been harassed by Eley for several weeks about his relationship with Lott.  Lott also allegedly told his trial counsel that he "saw and examined the entry and exit wounds on Mr. Eley" and asked one of the attorneys to act as a mannequin in order for Eley to "check the location of the gunshot wounds."  The complaint further alleges that during trial Lott failed to make timely objections to the jury's decisions not to grant him access to the evidence.  In his final issue on appeal, the SEC's Office of Inspector General issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors toÂ check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment in a real estate investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.Â The SEC's Complaint against Lott alleges that he violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the Complaint, the defendants consented to the entry of final judgments that permanently enjoin them from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, order them to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, and impose civil penalties of $10,000 and $20,000, respectively.  On August 2, 2018, the Honorable Judge of the United States District Court in Jackson entered a judgment ordering a temporary restraining order against Eley and prohibiting him from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any security deposit in the name of any SEC-registered broker, dealer, municipal securities dealer, penny stock dealer, or nationally recognized statistical rating organization. The order also ordered Lott to pay a $1,000 civil penalty and to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years.   The court also ordered that the jury consider Lott's offer of an officer-and-director bar against him, ordering him to be restrained and restrained, and ordering the trial counsel to
